1.title: DNS Compromise
1.description: Altering DNS records resulting in improper redirection.

4.title: DDoS Attack
4.description: Participating in distributed denial-of-service (usually part of botnet).

9.title: Open Proxy
9.description: Open proxy, open relay, or Tor exit node.

10.title: Web Spam
10.description: Comment/forum spam, HTTP referer spam, or other CMS spam.

11.title: Email Spam
11.description: Spam email content, infected attachments, and phishing emails. Note: Limit comments to only relevant information (instead of log dumps) and be sure to remove PII if you want to remain anonymous.

14.title: Port Scan
14.description: Scanning for open ports and vulnerable services.

18.title: Brute-Force
18.description: Credential brute-force attacks on webpage logins and services like SSH, FTP, SIP, SMTP, RDP, etc. This category is separate from DDoS attacks.

19.title: Bad Web Bot
19.description: Webpage scraping (for email addresses, content, etc) and crawlers that do not honor robots.txt. Excessive requests and user agent spoofing can also be reported here.

20.title: Exploited Host
20.description: Host is likely infected with malware and being used for other attacks or to host malicious content. The host owner may not be aware of the compromise. This category is often used in combination with other attack categories.

21.title: Web App Attack
21.description: Attempts to probe for or exploit installed web applications such as a CMS like WordPress/Drupal, e-commerce solutions, forum software, phpMyAdmin and various other software plugins/solutions.

22.title: SSH
22.description: Secure Shell (SSH) abuse. Use this category in combination with more specific categories.

23.title: IoT Targeted
23.description: Abuse was targeted at an "Internet of Things" type device. Include information about what type of device was targeted in the comments.
